paragraphs.zh-tw: I work with a species called "Bonobo." And I'm happy most of the time, because I think this is the happiest species on the planet. It's kind of a well-kept secret.
paragraphs.en: 我研究矮黑猩猩 工作時，我多半是快樂的 因為我覺得牠們是地球上最快樂的物種 這點還不太為人所知

paragraphs.zh-tw: This species lives only in the Congo. And they're not in too many zoos, because of their sexual behavior.
paragraphs.en: 矮黑猩猩只棲息在剛果 由於交配習性的關係，牠們很少出現在動物園

paragraphs.zh-tw: Their sexual behavior is too human-like for most of us to be comfortable with. But -- actually, we have a lot to learn from them, because they're a very egalitarian society and they're a very empathetic society.
paragraphs.en: 牠們的交配習性太像人了 也就是我們習慣的那樣 （笑） 但是...... （笑） 事實上，我們得向牠們學習的很多 牠們有著非常公平且富同理心的社會

paragraphs.zh-tw: And sexual behavior is not confined to one aspect of their life that they sort of set aside. It permeates their entire life.
paragraphs.en: 交配行為並不因只是生活的一部分 而被忽略 反之，這是牠們生活的全部

paragraphs.zh-tw: And it's used for communication. And it's used for conflict resolution.
paragraphs.en: 可以用來溝通 可以用來化解衝突

paragraphs.zh-tw: And I think perhaps somewhere in our history we sort of, divided our lives up into lots of parts. We divided our world up with lots of categories.
paragraphs.en: 我想，或許是在人類歷史的某個時間點 開始把生活分成好幾個部分 把世界切割成不同地域

paragraphs.zh-tw: And so everything sort of has a place that it has to fit. But I don't think that we were that way initially.
paragraphs.en: 每件事都得被歸檔在正確的位置 但我不認為我們的祖宗是這樣的

paragraphs.zh-tw: There are many people who think that the animal world is hard-wired and that there's something very, very special about man. Maybe it's his ability to have causal thought.
paragraphs.en: 很多人認為，動物凡事但憑反射直覺 人類是非常非常特別的物種 或許是思考的能力

paragraphs.zh-tw: Maybe it's something special in his brain that allows him to have language. Maybe it's something special in his brain that allows him to make tools or to have mathematics.
paragraphs.en: 或許是大腦有什麼特出之處 讓人類發展出語言 或許是大腦的特殊之處 讓人類能夠使用工具跟計算

paragraphs.zh-tw: Well, I don't know. There were Tasmanians who were discovered around the 1600s and they had no fire. They had no stone tools.
paragraphs.en: 是嗎？我不知道。十六世紀的時候 探險家發現了塔斯馬尼亞人。他們不用火 也沒有石器

paragraphs.zh-tw: To our knowledge they had no music. So when you compare them to the Bonobo, the Bonobo is a little hairier.
paragraphs.en: 就我所知，他們也沒有音樂 將矮黑猩猩跟塔斯馬尼亞人一起比較 除了矮黑猩猩毛多了些

paragraphs.zh-tw: He doesn't stand quite as upright. But there are a lot of similarities.
paragraphs.en: 跟不太能直立站著外 兩者有許多相似性

paragraphs.zh-tw: And I think that as we look at culture, we kind of come to understand how we got to where we are. And I don't really think it's in our biology; I think we've attributed it to our biology, but I don't really think it's there.
paragraphs.en: 我認為，研究文化 能夠幫助我們了解 我們是如何成為人 我不認為是我們的生物性讓我們變成人 是「成為人」這件事影響了我們的生物性 生物性跟「成為人」無關

paragraphs.zh-tw: So what I want to do now is introduce you to a species called the Bonobo. This is Kanzi.
paragraphs.en: 所以，我想跟各位分享的是 矮黑猩猩這種生物 這是Kanzi

paragraphs.zh-tw: He's a Bonobo. Right now, he's in a forest in Georgia.
paragraphs.en: 一隻矮黑猩猩 目前，牠住在喬治亞州的森林

paragraphs.zh-tw: His mother originally came from a forest in Africa. And she came to us when she was just at puberty, about six or seven years of age.
paragraphs.en: 牠的媽媽來自非洲的森林 我們見到牠時，牠才剛進入青春期 大概六七歲吧

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now this shows a Bonobo on your right, and a chimpanzee on your left. Clearly, the chimpanzee has a little bit harder time of walking.
paragraphs.en: 畫面上的右邊是一隻矮黑猩猩 左邊是黑猩猩 顯然的，黑猩猩比較不擅長行走

paragraphs.zh-tw: The Bonobo, although shorter than us and their arms still longer, is more upright, just as we are. This shows the Bonobo compared to an australopithecine like Lucy.
paragraphs.en: 雖然矮黑猩猩比我們矮，手臂較長 但比黑猩猩更能直立，像我們一樣行走 再比較矮黑猩猩跟與露西一類的南猿

paragraphs.zh-tw: As you can see, there's not a lot of difference between the way a Bonobo walks and the way an early australopithecine would have walked. As they turn toward us you'll see that the pelvic area of early australopithecines is a little flatter and doesn't have to rotate quite so much from side to side.
paragraphs.en: 矮黑猩猩的行走模式 跟南猿可能的行走方式 並沒有太大不同 觀察牠們的正面觀，可以注意到 早期南猿的骨盆腔較平 在兩腳交互移動時沒有太多的旋轉

paragraphs.zh-tw: So the -- the bipedal gait is a little easier. And now we see all four.
paragraphs.en: 因此，使用兩腳行走較容易 這是上述四個物種的比較

paragraphs.zh-tw: Video: Narrator: The wild Bonobo lives in central Africa, in the jungle encircled by the Congo River. Canopied trees as tall as 40 meters, 130 feet, grow densely in the area.
paragraphs.en: 影片中是棲息在中非的矮黑猩猩 牠們住在由剛果河包圍的叢林裡 這地區的林冠茂密 有40公尺高，也就是130英呎

paragraphs.zh-tw: It was a Japanese scientist who first undertook serious field studies of the Bonobo, almost three decades ago. Bonobos are built slightly smaller than the chimpanzee.
paragraphs.en: 有個日本科學家® 開始了矮黑猩猩的田野調查 大概是三十年前 矮黑猩猩比黑猩猩個頭略小

paragraphs.zh-tw: Slim-bodied, Bonobos are by nature very gentle creatures. Long and careful studies have reported many new findings on them.
paragraphs.en: 身材也瘦，天生是非常溫馴的動物 幾個長期追蹤的嚴謹研究，顯示一些新發現：

paragraphs.zh-tw: One discovery was that wild Bonobos often walk bidpedally. What's more, they are able to walk upright for long distances.
paragraphs.en: 首先：野生的矮黑猩猩常常利用雙腳行走 而且牠們還能直立地長途行走

paragraphs.zh-tw: Susan Savage-Rumbaugh (video): Let's go say hello to Austin first and then go to the A frame. SS: This is Kanzi and I, in the forest.
paragraphs.en: 先去跟Austin打聲招呼，然後再去A區。 SS: Kanzi跟我在森林裡

paragraphs.zh-tw: None of the things you will see in this particular video are trained. None of them are tricks.
paragraphs.en: 影片裡所發生的是，沒有一個是經過訓練的結果 也沒有一個是偽造的

paragraphs.zh-tw: They all happened to be captured on film spontaneously, by NHK of Japan. We have eight Bonobos.
paragraphs.en: 影片裡的一切都是自發行為 這是由日本NHK所拍攝的 我們有八隻矮黑猩猩

paragraphs.zh-tw: Video: Look at all this stuff that's here for our campfire. SS: An entire family at our research centre.
paragraphs.en: 影片：請看營火旁有什麼 SS: 我們的研究中心有一整個黑猩猩家庭

paragraphs.zh-tw: Video: You going to help get some sticks? Good. We need more sticks, too.
paragraphs.en: 影片：想幫忙撿柴火嗎？ 很好 我們也需要些柴火

paragraphs.zh-tw: I have a lighter in my pocket if you need one. That's a wasps' nest.
paragraphs.en: 如果你想要，我口袋裡有打火機 那是個黃蜂巢

paragraphs.zh-tw: You can get it out. I hope I have a lighter.
paragraphs.en: 你們可以拿出來 希望我有打火機

paragraphs.zh-tw: You can use the lighter to start the fire. SS: So Kanzi is very interested in fire.
paragraphs.en: 這樣你就可以生火了 SS: 原來Kanzi對火有興趣

paragraphs.zh-tw: He doesn't do it yet without a lighter, but I think if he saw someone do it, he might be able to do -- make a fire without a lighter. He's learning about how to keep a fire going.
paragraphs.en: 沒有打火機，牠就不會生火 不過，如果牠看別人做一次，牠也許就能 不靠打火機生火 牠正在學怎麼讓火繼續燒

paragraphs.zh-tw: He's learning the uses for a fire, just by watching what we do with fire. This is a smile on the face of a Bonobo.
paragraphs.en: 牠正在學著用火 但只敢看著我們用 （笑） 矮黑猩猩的臉上有著微笑

paragraphs.zh-tw: These are happy vocalizations. Video: You're happy.
paragraphs.en: 這是開心的表示 影片：你很開心啊

paragraphs.zh-tw: You're very happy about this part. You've got to put some water on the fire. You see the water? Good job.
paragraphs.en: 你很喜歡這個部分吧 你得把水潑在火上。看到水了沒？ 很好

paragraphs.zh-tw: SS: Forgot to zip up the back half of his backpack. But he likes to carry things from place to place.
paragraphs.en: SS: 牠忘了要拉上背包的拉鍊 但牠很喜歡把東西帶來帶去

paragraphs.zh-tw: Video: Austin, I hear you saying "Austin." SS: He talks to other Bonobos at the lab, long-distance, farther than we can hear. This is his sister.
paragraphs.en: 影片：Austin, 我聽到你說Austin SS: 牠可以跟位在遠處，聽不見這裡動靜的 實驗室裡的矮黑猩猩溝通 這是Kanzi的姐姐

paragraphs.zh-tw: This is her first time to try to drive a golf cart. Video: Goodbye.
paragraphs.en: 牠第一次試著開高爾夫球車 影片：拜拜！ （笑）

paragraphs.zh-tw: SS: She's got the pedals down, but not the wheel. She switches from reverse to forward and she holds onto the wheel, rather than turns it.
paragraphs.en: SS: 牠踩下踏板，但沒有打方向盤 讓車子從後退變成前進 現在牠抓住方向盤，卻沒有轉動 （笑）

paragraphs.zh-tw: Like us, she knows that that individual in the mirror is her. (Music) Video: Narrator: By raising Bonobos in a culture that is both Bonobo and human, and documenting their development across two decades, scientists are exploring how cultural forces may have operated during human evolution.
paragraphs.en: 跟人類一樣，牠知道鏡子裡的影像是自己 （音樂） 影片：讓矮黑猩猩在融合了矮黑猩猩跟人類文化的環境中長大 並記錄牠們的成長長達二十多年 科學家得以了解文化力 （笑） 是如何影響人類演化的

paragraphs.zh-tw: His name is Nyota. It means "star" in Swahili.
paragraphs.en: 這是Nyota 在斯瓦希里語裡是星星的意思

paragraphs.zh-tw: (Music) Panbanisha is trying to give Nyota a haircut with a pair of scissors. In the wild, the parent Bonobo is known to groom its offspring.
paragraphs.en: （音樂） Panbanisha正試著用一對剪刀幫Nyota剪頭髮 已知野生矮黑猩猩的家長會幫小孩理毛

paragraphs.zh-tw: Here Panbanisha uses scissors, instead of her hands, to groom Nyota. Very impressive.
paragraphs.en: 現在Panbanisha正用剪刀而不是用手 幫Nyota理毛 很令人印象深刻吧

paragraphs.zh-tw: Subtle maneuvering of the hands is required to perform delicate tasks like this. Nyota tries to imitate Panbanisha by using the scissors himself.
paragraphs.en: 需要很精巧的手部運動 才能進行這樣的工作喔 Nyota也學Panbanisha使用剪刀

paragraphs.zh-tw: Realizing that Nyota might get hurt, Panbanisha, like any human mother, carefully tugs to get the scissors back. He can now cut through tough animal hide.
paragraphs.en: Panbanish知道Nyota可能會受傷 跟所有的人類媽媽一樣 牠小心地把剪刀拿回來 牠現在能用剪刀剪具韌性的動物皮毛

paragraphs.zh-tw: SS: Kanzi's learned to make stone tools. Video: Kanzi now makes his tools, just as our ancestors may have made them, two-and-a-half million years ago -- by holding the rocks in both hands, to strike one against the other.
paragraphs.en: SS: Kanzi正在學怎麼製作石器 影片：Kanzi正在做自己的工具 就跟我們的祖先一樣 兩百五十萬年前 人類祖先靠著兩手拿著石頭互相撞擊

paragraphs.zh-tw: He has learned that by using both hands and aiming his glancing blows, he can make much larger, sharper flakes. Kanzi chooses a flake he thinks is sharp enough.
paragraphs.en: 學會如何使用雙手 學會一拳中的 他能製作更大更尖銳的石片 Kanzi挑了一片他認為夠尖的石片

paragraphs.zh-tw: The tough hide is difficult to cut, even with a knife. The rock that Kanzi is using is extremely hard and ideal for stone tool making, but difficult to handle, requiring great skill.
paragraphs.en: 即使使用刀子，皮毛也很難切斷 Kanzi用的石頭非常硬 很適合拿來做成工具，卻很難使用 需要很多的技巧

paragraphs.zh-tw: Kanzi's rock is from Gona, Ethiopia and is identical to that used by our African ancestors two-and-a-half million years ago. These are the rocks Kanzi used and these are the flakes he made.
paragraphs.en: Kanzi的石頭來自衣索匹亞的Gona 跟我們的非洲祖先在兩百五十萬年前 使用的一模一樣 這是Kanzi用的石頭 而這些是它做的石片

paragraphs.zh-tw: The flat sharp edges are like knife blades. Compare them to the tools our ancestors used; they bear a striking resemblance to Kanzi's.
paragraphs.en: 尖銳的切緣就跟刀鋒一樣 跟我們祖先使用的石器比較 兩者相似得不可思議

paragraphs.zh-tw: Panbanisha is longing to go for a walk in the woods. She keeps staring out the window.
paragraphs.en: Panbanisha想到樹林裡走走 牠盯著窗戶看

paragraphs.zh-tw: SS: This is -- let me show you something we didn't think they would do. Video: For several days now, Panbanisha has not been outside.
paragraphs.en: SS: 這...讓我給你們看些不可思議的事 影片：Panbanisha已經有好幾天沒出去了

paragraphs.zh-tw: SS: I normally talk about language. Video: Then Panbanisha does something unexpected.
paragraphs.en: SS: 我常常談論語言 影片：Panbanish做了件出乎人意料的事

paragraphs.zh-tw: SS: But since I'm advised not to do what I normally do, I haven't told you that these apes have language. It's a geometric language.
paragraphs.en: SS: 但有人建議我別一成不變 我沒告訴你們這些猩猩有語言吧！ 這是種地理語言

paragraphs.zh-tw: Video: She takes a piece of chalk and begins writing something on the floor. What is she writing? SS: She's also saying the name of that, with her voice.
paragraphs.en: 影片：牠拿了粉筆 在地板上寫些東西 寫些什麼呢？ SS: 牠也有自己的聲音，能說出名字

paragraphs.zh-tw: Video: Now she comes up to Dr. Sue and starts writing again. SS: These are her symbols on her keyboard.
paragraphs.en: 影片：現在牠在SS身邊，又開始寫 SS: 這在牠的鍵盤上代表牠的符號

paragraphs.zh-tw: (Music) They speak when she touches them. Video: Panbanisha is communicating to Dr. Sue where she wants to go.
paragraphs.en: （音樂） 在牠按觸鍵時，會發出聲音 影片：Panbanisha正在跟Sue說牠要去哪裡

paragraphs.zh-tw: "A frame" represents a hut in the woods. Compare the chalk writing with the lexigram on the keyboard.
paragraphs.en: A區中的森林裡有頂帽子 比較Kanzi用粉筆畫的跟鍵盤上的符號

paragraphs.zh-tw: Panbanisha began writing the lexigrams on the forest floor. SS (video): Very nice. Beautiful, Panbanisha.
paragraphs.en: Panbanisha在森林地面上畫符號 很好，真漂亮啊，Panbanisha

paragraphs.zh-tw: SS: At first we didn't really realize what she was doing, until we stood back and looked at it and rotated it. Video: This lexigram also refers to a place in the woods.
paragraphs.en: SS: 一開始我們不知道牠在做什麼 直到我們退一步，並換個方向看 影片：這個符號表示林子裡一個地方

paragraphs.zh-tw: The curved line is very similar to the lexigram. The next symbol Panbanisha writes represents "collar." It indicates the collar that Panbanisha must wear when she goes out.
paragraphs.en: 這條曲線跟那個符號很接近 牠畫的下一個符號代表項圈 也就是牠每回出門都得戴的項圈

paragraphs.zh-tw: SS: That's an institutional requirement. Video: This symbol is not as clear as the others, but one can see Panbanisha is trying to produce a curved line and several straight lines.
paragraphs.en: SS: 這是研究機構的要求 影片：這個符號沒有其他的清楚 可以看到Panbanish正試著畫一條曲線 跟數條直線

paragraphs.zh-tw: Researchers began to record what Panbanisha said, by writing lexigrams on the floor with chalk. Panbanisha watched.
paragraphs.en: 研究人員開始記錄Panbanisha 藉著畫畫想告訴我們什麼 Panbanisha看了看

paragraphs.zh-tw: Soon she began to write as well. The Bonobo's abilities have stunned scientists around the world.
paragraphs.en: 很快地牠就能畫出來 矮黑猩猩的學習能力震驚了全世界的科學家

paragraphs.zh-tw: How did they develop? SS (video): We found that the most important thing for permitting Bonobos to acquire language is not to teach them. It's simply to use language around them, because the driving force in language acquisition is to understand what others, that are important to you, are saying to you.
paragraphs.en: 這樣的能力是怎麼來的？ SS: 我們最重要的發現是 要讓矮黑猩猩學會語言，並不需要教牠 只要利用周遭的語言 因為學習語言的動力 是為了瞭解對自己重要的人在說什麼

paragraphs.zh-tw: Once you have that capacity, the ability to produce language comes rather naturally and rather freely. So we want to create an environment in which Bonobos, like all of the individuals with whom they are interacting -- we want to create an environment in which they have fun, and an environment in which the others are meaningful individuals for them.
paragraphs.en: 一旦你有了語言能力 創造語言 是非常自然而隨興的事 因此，我們想創造一個 讓每一隻矮黑猩猩都能互動的環境 讓每隻猩猩可以玩遊戲 跟每一隻猩猩對其他猩猩 都有意義的環境

paragraphs.zh-tw: Narrator: This environment brings out unexpected potential in Kanzi and Panbanisha. Panbanisha is enjoying playing her harmonica, until Nyota, now one year old, steals it.
paragraphs.en: 而這個環境讓Kanzi跟Panbanisha發展出 不在我們預期中的能力 Panbanisha很喜歡吹口琴 直到有一天，口琴被現在已經一歲Nyota的偷了

paragraphs.zh-tw: Then he peers eagerly into his mother's mouth. Is he looking for where the sound came from? Dr. Sue thinks it's important to allow such curiosity to flourish.
paragraphs.en: 牠直盯著媽媽的嘴巴看 牠在找聲音從哪來的嗎？ SS認為，讓這樣的好奇心得以醞釀是重要的

paragraphs.zh-tw: This time Panbanisha is playing the electric piano. She wasn't forced to learn the piano; she saw a researcher play the instrument and took an interest.
paragraphs.en: 這次，Panbanisha在彈電子琴 牠不是被逼著彈 牠看到研究人員彈琴，感到興趣

paragraphs.zh-tw: Researcher: Go ahead. Go ahead. I'm listening. Do that real fast part that you did. Yeah, that part.
paragraphs.en: 繼續啊！繼續啊！我在聽呢 再彈一次你剛剛彈很快的部分。對，就是那裡

paragraphs.zh-tw: Narrator: Kanzi plays the xylophone; using both hands he enthusiastically accompanies Dr. Sue's singing. Kanzi and Panbanisha are stimulated by this fun-filled environment, which promotes the emergence of these cultural capabilities.
paragraphs.en: Kanzi熱切地用兩手演奏木琴 幫SS伴奏 Kanzi跟Panbanisha都受到 這樣有趣的環境刺激 讓牠們表現出這些文明的行為 （笑）

paragraphs.zh-tw: Researcher: OK, now get the monsters. Get them. Take the cherries too.
paragraphs.en: 現在，把鬼吃掉 吃櫻桃

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now watch out, stay away from them now. Now you can chase them again. Time to chase them.
paragraphs.en: 小心！離鬼遠一點 現在可以追了，去追吧

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now you have to stay away. Get away. Run away. Run.
paragraphs.en: 現在得逃遠一點，跑 跑啊！跑！

paragraphs.zh-tw: Now we can chase them again. Go get them. Oh no! Good Kanzi. Very good. Thank you so much.
paragraphs.en: 現在可以追了，吃掉吧 喔！不！ 好，Kanzi，很好，謝謝

paragraphs.zh-tw: Narrator: None of us, Bonobo or human, can possibly even imagine? SS: So we have a bi-species environment, we call it a "panhomoculture." We're learning how to become like them. We're learning how to communicate with them, in really high-pitched tones.
paragraphs.en: 想不到吧？無論是人還是矮黑猩猩都想不到吧？ SS: 這樣讓人類跟矮黑猩猩聚集在一起的環境，稱之為泛人類文化 我們正學著怎樣更像猩猩一點 我們正學著如何用高頻音 跟牠們溝通

paragraphs.zh-tw: We're learning that they probably have a language in the wild. And they're learning to become like us.
paragraphs.en: 我們漸漸明白野生猩猩可能也有自己的語言 而猩猩們也學著變得更像我們人類

paragraphs.zh-tw: Because we believe that it's not biology; it's culture. So we're sharing tools and technology and language with another species.
paragraphs.en: 而我們相信，這不是因為生物性，而是文化 我們跟其他的物種，有著相同的工具、 技術、跟語言

paragraphs.zh-tw: Thank you.
paragraphs.en: 謝謝

title: Susan Savage Rumbaugh On Apes That Write
